text:
This Wednesday marks the start of the #16DaysOfActivism to #EndGenderBasedViolence - a time for global action to increase awareness and galvanize advocacy on behalf of women, girls, and marginalized genders.

To build a world free of gender-based violence it is no longer possible to only rely on the grassroots activists who dedicate their lives to doing this work, we must all play our part. Are you in?

#OrangeTheWorld

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
We’re determined to end violence against women and girls: Are you in?

text:
We’re SO CLOSE to a new anti-FGM law in the United States! In September, the U.S. House of Representatives passed the Stop FGM Act of 2020, and it was then referred to the Senate Committee on the Judiciary. The bill has the full support of the Department of Justice. All the Judiciary Committee chairs need to do is bring it out of committee for a vote on the Senate Floor.

The Senate session will end within the next two weeks, which doesn’t leave much time for a vote - but it CAN happen. And it MUST: if the Stop FGM Act of 2020 doesn’t get passed this year, supporters will have to start all over again from scratch next year with the new Congress.

Please join us in calling on the Judiciary Committee to protect women and girls from FGM in the U.S. today!

https://www.equalitynow.org/us_protect_women_and_girls_from_female_genital_mutilation_fgm

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
United States: Protect women and girls from Female Genital Mutilation (FGM)

text:
Along with six other women in Georgia, I’m sharing my story of escaping child marriage.

Three years on and I am defining my own future. I know my rights, and I will continue to fight for them. I will continue to campaign to end child marriage.

I want parents to know the importance of listening to their children, and centering their happiness.

I want girls and women across Georgia to know they have rights, and that there is support out there if they need it.

Read our stories in 'Courage: Survivors of child marriage in Georgia share their stories' at equalitynow.org/courage_georgia

text:
Whilst child marriage and forced marriage are against the law in Georgia, a 2018 UNICEF report found that among women aged 20-24, 14% were married by the age of 18 in Georgia. The Ministry of the Interior of Georgia has recorded 34 cases of bride kidnapping in the first 9 months of 2020. In Courage, released by Goga Khatiashvili and Equality Now, seven women, forced to marry as children, tell their stories.

Dedicated to everyone who speaks up about violence, the publication serves as a reminder to us all that girls and women have the right to live free from violence.

#EndChildMarriage #ListenToSurvivors

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
Courage: Survivors of child marriage in Georgia share their stories

text:
Across the world, societal norms that consider women and girls as the property of their family see girls married to older men.

With COVID-19 predicted to increase rates of child marriage around the world, we’re continuing to work with partners around the world to support survivors to advocate for change and ensure laws protect girls from child marriage.

Read more: http://ow.ly/C6KY50CD9jm

#16Days #OrangeTheWorld #EndChildMarriage

text:
📣 If it isn't intersectional, it isn't feminism 📣

People’s experiences of patriarchal systems and structures are not uniform, with women and girls from marginalized communities facing intersecting forms of discrimination.

Throughout #16DaysOfActivism and beyond we remain committed to changing the system and making equality reality for all women and girls around the world.

Read more: http://ow.ly/kwAY50CD5IS

#IntersectionalFeminism #16Days #OrangeTheWorld

text:
Equality Now is saddened to hear that Vanessa Kogan, a prominent human rights activist and Director of the Justice Initiative project (Проект "Правовая инициатива") in Russia, faces expulsion from the country. She has been given two weeks to leave Russia, after her residence permit was revoked on December 2.

"Today I learned that 11 years of living in Russia, 2 children born in the Russian Federation with Russian citizenship, 11 years of paid taxes are not enough to be considered “our own”. On the contrary, you can just take everything and tear it off in an instant: the residence permit is canceled, 2 weeks to leave the country”, wrote Vanessa on her Facebook.

Justice Initiative has been operating in Russia since 2001 and the project provides legal support to Russian citizens seeking justice for human rights abuses in both local courts and the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. Justice Initiative also works in Russia’s North Caucasus, documenting abuses by law enforcement and the military, and gender discrimination. The project presented the case of Valeria Volodina to the ECHR, according to which the Strasbourg Court in 2019 issued the first ruling on domestic violence in Russia.

We stand in solidarity with Vanessa and urge the Russian authorities to immediately annul this decision.

#WHRD #HumanRightsDefenders #16DaysOfActivism #16Days

THEGUARDIAN.COM
Russia moves to expel American human rights activist

text:
Karen Robinson has been fantasizing about an ideal world for women; equal pay, respect, education for girls, control over our own bodies, and all dresses have secret pockets...

She's one of a host of celebrities, activists, and supporters of equal rights for women and girls joining our first-ever virtual #MakeEqualityReality Gala this Thursday 3 December at 5.30pm PST/ 8.30 PM EST. And we’ve held a seat just for you.

RSVP now at www.equalitynow.org/gala. Can't watch along live? Don't worry - once you've got the link, you can watch it anytime.

#KarenRobinson #SchittsCreek #FreeEvents #GenderEquality #DressesWithPockets

text:
Ahead of #GivingTuesday, we've been thinking about the world we want to live in. It's a world where:

🧡 Every woman and girl knows her rights
🧡 Survivors of violence are able to voice their concerns without fear of stigma or belief
🧡 Justice systems work for women and girls, not against them
🧡 Survivors are able to access support services that are centered around their needs
🧡 Survivors are empowered to move forward with agency

The work ahead of us will take more than #16Days, but we aren't cowed. Ahead of #GivingTuesday2020 donate whatever you can to support our work to #MakeEqualityReality.

www.equalitynow.org/donate

text:
2020 has been a year like no other, with the continued rise of authoritarianism, police brutality against Black men and women, and the rollback of human rights, and women’s rights in particular. There have been continued attempts to silence women human rights defenders across the world from Iran to Zimbabwe.

This International Women Human Rights Defenders Day, learn more about some of the women and organizations on the frontlines of the movement to protect and promote human rights across the world, including:

👉 Azza Soliman, co-founder of مؤسسة قضايا المرأة المصرية - Centre for Egyptian Women Legal Assistance,
👉 Dina Smailova, Head of Kazakh women's rights organization Немолчиkz,
👉 Loujain alHathloul and other detained #SaudiWomen,
👉 Dalit activists Manjula Pradeep and Manisha Mashaal, founder of Swabhiman society,
👉 Puerto Rican organization Proyecto Matria
👉 the migrant women who went public about forced sterilizations in immigration detention in the United States, and
👉 Zimbabwean women Joanna Mamombe, Cecilia Chimbiri, and Netsai Marova.

#16DaysOfActivism #OrangeTheWorld #HumanRightsDefenders

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
International Women Human Rights Defenders Day 2020: The women working to make equality reality

We’ve teamed up with Athlete A Film for #16DaysOfActivism to highlight the bravery of the #NassarSurvivors & the ecosystem that allows sexual abuse to persist. Predators commit abuse but individuals & institutions grant them impunity.

Read more on our website and watch the #AthleteA documentary on Netflix.

Not Just One Bad Man

text:
Caste-based sexual violence is being used as a weapon to oppress Dalit women, capitalizing on gendered power dynamics to maintain caste hierarchies across the country.

These hierarchies are used to silence Dalit women and girls through threats and a consistent failure by the police to register complaints by survivors, resulting in a culture of “violence, silence, and impunity”.

Read more about our latest report, released in partnership with Swabhiman society, in The Swaddle.

#EndCasteBasedSexualViolence #HaryanaDalitWomenSpeakOut #16DaysOfActivism

THESWADDLE.COM
Oppressor-Caste Solidarity Drives Culture of Silence Around Rapes of Dalit Girls in Haryana: Report

text:
The recent Hathras case is just one example of the widespread sexual violence taking place against Dalit women and girls across India.

Our new report, launched together with Swabhiman society, found Dalit survivors of sexual violence in Haryana, are facing severe obstacles to accessing justice as well as intersectional caste and gender discrimination.

The time is now to end caste based sexual violence, and it’s on all of us. Will you join us in calling on the Haryana State Government to end sexual violence and caste based discrimination? Every voice counts.

#HaryanaDalitWomenSpeakOut #EndCasteBasedSexualViolence #16DaysofActivism

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
India: Haryana Government must act to end caste-based sexual violence

text:
Manisha Mashaal, the founder of Swabhiman society, is an inspiring and resilient voice fighting in the forefronts of the movement addressing caste based violence against Dalit women and girls in Haryana, India.

Ahead of the release of our joint report on barriers to accessing justice faced by #Dalit women and girls in #Haryana, we spoke to her about her activism, the role of the media in promoting access to justice and what all of us can do to contribute to positive change.

#HaryanaDalitWomenSpeakOut #EndCasteBasedSexualViolence #16DaysofActivism

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
Addressing the Intersection of Caste and Sexual Violence in Haryana, India

text:
Brisa de Angulo didn’t get justice when she was raped as a teen. She endured three trials in Bolivia, but her rapist has yet to be held accountable for any of his crimes. In 2012, Brisa filed a case before the Inter-American Commission of Human Rights, who referred it to the Inter-American Court of Human Rights this past August 7th, 2020. Today, Equality Now and the rest of Brisa's legal team officially filed the brief for Brisa’s case before the Court, with the hearing expected in 2021. Now, almost 20 years after her ordeal started, her case could set a legal precedent in Bolivia and for the Americas which all member States would be held to, improving the lives of girls and women throughout the Western Hemisphere.

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
An Important Step Toward Accountability for Sexual Violence in Bolivia and Beyond

text:
Two years ago, Imani* was raped by her neighbor and became pregnant as a result. She was 16 at the time and in primary school back in Moshi, Tanzania.

Imani loved sciences and geography and wanted to work as a doctor or a nurse when she completed her studies.

Imani represents tens of thousands of adolescent school-going girls in Tanzania who can longer access education owing to the ban prohibiting pregnant girls and teenage mothers from attending school.

And despite numerous efforts urging Tanzania to lift the ban, lack of political will has been a great obstacle.

We, in collaboration with our partners, have therefore today filed a case against Tanzania at the African Court on Human and People’s Rights in Arusha to challenge this policy and have it lifted.

We stand with Imani and every other girl that she represents. Do you?

Share this post to demand that Tanzania #LetGirlsLearn and read more about the filing on our website ➡️ https://bit.ly/2ITDn0B

#EndSexualViolence #WaacheMabintiWasome #WorldChildrensDay #WorldChildrensDay2020 #GirlsRights #GirlsEducation

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
Court case filed against Tanzania to overturn ban on pregnant girls attending school

text:
An analysis of Kuwait’s Penal Code released today by Equality Now and Abolish Article 153, reveals the extent to which Kuwait’s laws are failing to protect women and girls:

➡️ Article 182 allows rapists to escape punishment by marrying the woman or girl they raped, a provision actively condones and rewards sexual violence

➡️ Article 153 provides a lenient sentence for a man who kills his female relatives, a provision rooted in valuing ‘honor’ over the human rights of women and girls;

➡️ the Penal Code does not explicitly criminalize marital rape, leaving women vulnerable to sexual violence committed with impunity

➡️ and the definition of rape is reliant on the use of force, threats or deception rather than being grounded in consent.

It’s time to abolish laws that see women and girls as vessels of their family’s honor, and build an equal world that works for our mothers, our sisters, our daughters, our friends, our communities. Join Kuwaiti activists calling for reform today.

#EndSexualViolence #MarryYourRapist

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
Justice over honor: Kuwait should amend its Penal Code to protect women and girls from sexual violence

text:
Equality Now has remained a beacon for women's rights during this tumultuous year, and you can help support our work by buying from these brands who celebrate gender equality and the power of women. Equality Now is proud to partner with businesses and companies that put women at the core of their mission, and promote values of inclusivity, transparency, and equality.

We compiled a list of some amazing feminist brands you can confidently support, knowing they are doing their part to create a just world for women and girls. Buy gifts that make a difference this year.

https://www.equalitynow.org/feminist_gift_guide_2020

text:
What are you doing on December 3rd? Fancy spending the evening with Karamo Brown and Margaret Atwood from the comfort of your living room? Join us at our first-ever, virtual global gala.

Join us and some of your favorite artists and activists for an unforgettable evening spotlighting those who inspire us, support us, and help us take action in the fight for equal rights for women and girls around the world.

For the first time ever, we are excited to announce that our gala will be broadcast live to a global audience.

Register to watch the live broadcast for free today

👉👉 equalitynow.org/gala_2020 👈👈

text:
Due to #COVID19, 13 million more girls are at risk of #ChildMarriage, and 2 million more could undergo female genital mutilation by 2030. We can't let this happen.

Today we are joining with Girls Not Brides: The Global Partnership to End Child Marriage and the Global Platform for Action to End FGM/C to call on the leaders of the #GenerationEquality Actions Coalition on Gender-Based Violence to commit to ending
#FGM and child, early and forced marriage (CEFM).

Sign this open letter and call on leaders to ensure girls are free to decide their futures.

English ➡️ https://bit.ly/LetterEng
Español ➡️ https://bit.ly/LetterEsp
Français ➡️ https://bit.ly/LetterFra

text:
While child marriage has risen during the pandemic, the virus did not create societal conditions that judged a girl’s worth on her ability to be a wife.

While domestic care-workers have been unable to receive paid sick leave, it did not create an economy that devalued reproductive labor.

While government relief packages have excluded refugees and undocumented immigrants, it did not create political institutions that preferenced the powerful and privileged at the expense of the marginalized.

But what it did do, was force the world to acknowledge that women and girls continue to face both sex and gender-based discrimination. Read more about why we can't let this opportunity to define a new, inclusive future pass us by. ⬇️

EQUALITYNOW.ORG
2020 has been a year like no other, 2021 must be the year we change the game
